title: If “flattening the curve” and “slowing the spread” means that’s all we’re really doing, then does that suggest we will eventually all be exposed to the corona virus in time? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not at all. It depends on how good of a job we do with the mitigation policies, compliance and enforcement. With strong restrictions on travel, keeping schools closed, staying home and social distancing over at least a month but preferably two, combined with protective gear and distancing for essential workers we can greatly decrease the number of people exposed to the coronavirus. The virus can't travel on it's own or live without hosts. If everyone stays home we can starve the virus and many people will never be exposed. In fact the mitigation effort is already beginning to show results in the US. The virus is still increasing, but not quite as fast. But we need to continue the restrictions for at least another month and resist the pressure (in the US) to “re-open" things prematurely. In my state and many others we just started the official “lockdown" about 2 weeks ago and some states even later. The virus has an incubation time of at least 2 weeks and then several more weeks if people get sick, and we still have some exposure to each other from essential work and activities. And unfortunately people are still traveling and spreading it that way. Comprehensive testing and tracking with targeted quarantine can also decrease the number of people exposed, and eliminate the need to restrict entire populations.

Flattening the curve means that THIS season of CV will pass without complete devastation. What’s not clear is what happens next. If the virus follows the typical path for coronaviruses, we’ll get a break over the summer with minimal infections while the medical community catches their breath and companies ramp up production of PPE and testing supplies. Then in October or November it’ll come crashing back. IF we’re ready we’ll quarantine those affected, test everyone and prevent a widespread infection. Then we’ll just “hold on” until the vaccine or an effective treatment becomes available in early 2021. If the virus remains common and virulent during the summer, then it’ll be social distance until we can get it down to low levels, then testing and PPE and pockets of severe disease until 2021. It’s possible it’ll fade on its own, but I wouldn’t bank on that. If the vaccine works then everyone won’t have to be exposed, in fact it’ll be a bit like small pox, it might be possible to completely stamp it out (might have to immunize our pets, too, since it apparently can infect dogs and big cats).

Yes, pretty much. The idea behind “flattening the curve” is trying to prevent the medical system being overwhelmed due to being swamped by more cases than it can handle. By feeding them through at a more ordered rate (a) fewer people will die of Covid-19, and (b) fewer people will die of other things (because our hospitals are not overwhelmed). But it is not a cure and it is not a vaccine. It is basically a play for time. Time to get a vaccine. Time to maybe get a cure. And time to build up at least some segment of the population with a degree immunity. Someone I respect greatly once said to me: sometimes the only viable short term plan is to just try and stay standing long enough that the medium term matters.

Not unless a bunch of selfish idiots decide they might as well go “get it over with”. There are at least three reasons to “flatten the curve”: If the number of cases at the peak exceeds the available medical facilities, some of the victims will not get oxygen or ventilators and will die needlessly. (Even some young people, in case you’re one and think you’re invulnerable.)The longer we can delay the spread, the better chance medical researchers have to test various drugs to see which ones help fight the symptoms of COVID-19.The longer we can delay the spread, the better chance that a vaccine will be developed, at which point no one needs to die.STAY HOME!

Yes, that's the way of viruses. There's no cure, just the relief of symptoms, and in this case the hope that the health services may keep you alive somehow until your immune system catches up. We, the elderly and infirm, will be lucky indeed to survive this when we eventually catch it. We don't have any need to be encouraged to stay home in quarantine. We have cottened-on from the beginning and manned our barricades to keep folk out. Yes, we would starve if not for the kindness of friends bringing home shopping, and very kind they have been risking their own lives for ours. We are not proud of our actions. We know we are living on borrowed time. We are simply enjoying what time we may have left. Not much of a reward for a life of continuous hard work. Bless all health service and essential services providers. We will keep a place for you in the next world.

Some estimates are that 40–80% of the population will get infected. It certainly seems that unless you live in isolation and never come into contact with someone that is shedding virus particles, that infection is pretty unavoidable. When a large percentage of the population has become infected, there is a phenomenon called herd immunity and no more infections occur. It is doubtful that everyone will become infected. Even if large numbers are infected, most are likely to experience mild disease with little or no symptoms. We worry about the severe infections, overwhelming the health care system and death. There is still much unknown about this virus and the behavior. Certainly, we can limit exposure with aggressive testing and protecting the most vulnerable segments of the population. If someone is immune, they can return to work and move our country back to a new “normal”.

The gentler curve results in fewer people infected at this critical moment in time — preventing a surge that would inundate the healthcare system and ultimately, one hopes, resulting in fewer deaths. “What we need to do is flatten that down,” said Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, during the coronavirus task force briefing at the White House on a Tuesday evening in early March. “You do that with trying to interfere with the natural flow of the outbreak.”The infographic reminded Dr. Harris of something similar that he had designed years earlier for a pandemic preparedness training program. “Folks in the preparedness and public health community have been thinking about all of these issues for many years,” Dr. Harris said in an email. “Understanding and managing surge is an important part of preparedness.”

No you can’t catch it if you stay home and don’t associate with others who may be contaminated. If the virus has no new hosts it dies out. That is what self isolation is about, it flattens the contamination rate which will then begin the death of the virus. One infected person can contaminate 400 other and each of those individuals can contaminate another 400 each. Do the maths! If people stay away from each other the virus has no new hosts so either dies because the contaminated person dies or dies because the contaminated person beats the virus.

It could mean this… But with fewer infections over time, there won't be too much pressure on the available health care resources to manage the infections. Currently, symptomatic treatment has proved successful especially on the younger people without pre-existing medical conditions, as long as one has access to good medical care plus good immunity, they will be able to fight the virus on their own. That's what flattening the curve is all about. During this time, a vaccine could be got too as several vaccine trials are ongoing. And hopefully we all won't be exposed to the corona virus...

Sorta. There is currently no vaccine for CoVid 19. There are several promising candidates, but none are presently approved by use. That is true everywhere, not just the US. It is reasonable to assume that the majority of the population will be exposed. We may “catch a break:” as the weather improves. Viruses don’t do well in warn weather. WE may also see a resurgence when the weather turns back, in the fall. We’re pretty much “stuck” at this time. Our best course appears to be controlling the number of cases that the health care system is coping with at any point in time.

Without a vaccine it is quite likely it will continue to return year after year until so much of the herd is made immune that it can not easily transfer from one compatible host to another. That does not mean that everyone will have to get it. It just means that the virus can not find enough hosts to remain viable because it has to transfer from person to person and not float around in the air until finds someone.
No, because when enough people have immunity and the virus can’t spread then it will die out. Some people who naturally don’t have much contact with other people may never get it.

It means that it is slowing the spread of the coronavirus. They are trying to slow the exposure of the disease while they are racing for a vaccine. That means that not all of us will be exposed to the Disease. They are trying to lessen it so that less and less people get infected.

Ideally, a vaccine will be available for general use before everyone is exposed to the novel coronavirus. Once 95% of the world’s population is inoculated against COVID-19, it will fade away as measles did.
Yep, probably, until the vaccine is done (12–18 months).I just hope that no one is useing my respirator when I need it. High risk, in the age group, did some virology a long time ago. realist here.
40–70% of the world population is likely to be infected with SARS-CoV-2 in the next year or so.
